are concerns the Indian iant could see cases jump back up.Data from Public Health Englandshows a rise in cases from  to , this week in the UK, with the agency saying cases were ldquorising in the community and it was assessing the impact and severity of the iant.One response being considered is bringing forward the date for a second dose of vaccine for eligible groups to increase protection.Health Secretary Matt Hancock said the situation was being monitored carefully and the Government ldquowill not hesitate to take further actionnecessary.However, a small number of areas are seeing a rise in cases as the India iant spreads across the UK.The Prime Minister has said there is "increasing concern" about the iant and warned the emergence of further new iants "pose a potentially lethal danger".Where is the India iant dominant Surge testing has been under way in parts of Bolton since  May, after Public Health Englandconfirmed the town is one of the main locations of the India iant, which was reclassied as a lsquoiant of concernrsquo last week.Cases of the iant in England increased from  to  as of  May, according to PHE figures, with almost half of these related to travel or contact with a traveller.The majority of cases of the India Covid strain are concentrated in the north-west of England, predominantly in Bolton, and in London.The iant is also thought to be the reason behind half of coronavirus infections in Bedford, Blackburn with Darwen and South Northamptonshire, although these outbreaks are still small.Greater Manchester Mayor Andy Burnham has submitted a request to the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation that all over-s in Bolton, along with the rest of the Greater Manchester area, are able to receive a Covid- vaccination ldquoto mitigate the risks of spread in those communities where we are seeing more transmission.     There are also around  to  cases of the India iant in parts of Scotland, including Glasgow, with these cases again connected to travel.The India Covid iant, officially known as B.., was first detected in India in October.It has been designated a ldquoiant of concern by PHE as it is thought to be at least as transmissible as the iant detected in Kent last year, known as B, which is now dominant in the UK.PHE said there is currently no evidence to suggest that the new Indian iant is more serious than previous mutations, nor is there evidence which indicates that this version of the Indian iant is resistant to current vaccines.Health experts said they ldquohavenrsquot seen any hint of a current Covid iant that can fully evade the effectiveness of vaccines.On Wednesday , the European Medicines Agency said it was ldquopretty confident that vaccines currently in use will be effective against the Indian iant, a view that has been echoed by some British scientists.However, Professor James Naismith from the University of Oxford said not enough is known to say for sure whether the iant could frustrate the UKrsquos vaccination programme.Speaking on BBC Radio rsquos Today programme, he said: ldquoThe vaccines donrsquot  per cent prevent infection for people.ldquoWhat they do is, they almost  per cent prevent hospitalisation and serious illness.ldquoWe donrsquot know enough to know yet whether the Indian strain will behave dferently than that.ldquoSo even the regular virus can infect people who have been vaccinated and sometimes you do get reinfection.Could the iant delay lockdown ending The growing number of India Covid iant cases in the UK has sparked concerns that the lting of lockdown restrictions, which is set for  June in England, could now be delayed.Ministers have also not ruled out re-introducing local lockdowns in areas where the iant of concern is increasing.Foreign Office minister James Cleverly said that the government will make decisions based on the data, and measures will be eased ldquoat a pace and in a way which is safe.Symptoms to look forThe main symptoms of coronavirus to look for include:a high temperature ndash this means you feel hot to touch on your chest or back a new, continuous cough ndash this means coughing a lot for more than an hour, or three or more coughing episodes in  hours a loss or change to your sense of smell or taste ndash this means youve noticed you cannot smell or taste anything, or things smell or taste dferent to normalMost people with symptoms have at least one of these symptoms, although some do not experience any. title: penarth ramblers explore history nature walk
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityIt was girl power when ten female walkers joined Joy and sheepdog Bracken from Penarth and District Ramblers at Penarth clftop for an . mile walk, with no stiles only gates and which would see them experiencing the weather of all four seasons in one day. They set off on a socially distanced walk in lovely spring sunshine across the old pitch and putt course before joining part of the old railway line, now a walk and cycle way, and heading through a built up area Lavernock Road led them into Cosmeston Country Park.Past the eastern lake with its floating jetty where canoes can be safely launched and making their way through the eastern paddock with its carpet of pretty cowslips, open meadows led them towards Old Cogan Hall Farm, where they deviated into the churchyard of St Peterrsquos for morning break in glorious warm sunshine reminiscent of summer. Admiring the herring bone masonry which dates to Celtic and Saxon times and the ancient yew trees that could even pre-date this lovely old church, which allegedly is the oldest building in Penarth and hearing some of its long and interesting history, it fell into disrepair in the th century. By the th century the ruinous building was a cattle shelter until the latter part of the rsquos when the rd Marquis of Bute was persuaded to pay for its renovation.Mile Road built by the Bute family led them to the western paddock and through the sun-dappled Cogan Wood to re-enter fields where a footbridge led them across the Sully Brook for the short climb up to Home Farm, with its glorious views towards the eastern end of Barry and the surrounding farmland. Exiting through a gate, some road walking in a southerly direction brought them into Sully village and pounding pavements to reach the Jubilee Hall and the cricket field, the full beauty of Sully Bay with its views across the Bristol Channel towards the Somerset coastline and Hayes Point to the west confronted them.     With the wind beginning to pick up they tramped by track and field to the public slipway at Sully beach and stopped for lunch utilising rocks for seating whilst gazing eastwards towards Sully Island and Flat and Steep Holm beyond, as clouds thickened overhead and the temperature dropped making it feel more like autumn.Time to move on along part of the long distance Wales Coast Path, through the playing fields to exit onto Beach Road, following it to the car park of the Captainrsquos We where there were only a few people sitting at outdoor tables for food and drink, not really enjoyable in the cool breeze.The fairly quiet St Maryrsquos Well Bay Road brought them up past The Bay Caravan Park and into fields with growing crops where, without any warning a sudden short sharp shower of rain engulfed the group forcing coats to be swtly donned.Crossing a wooden footbridge into the delightful Lavernock Nature Reserve the grassy path led them into the remains of the WW gun emplacements. Initially in the late rsquos the original Lavernock Gun Battery was built to protect the Bristol and Cardf shipyards and the Bristol Channel, but unfortunately most of the original buildings now lie underneath the caravan park.Being bombarded by a short hail storm whilst moving on through the nature reserve, lovingly cared for by volunteers and passing the man-made pond with its surrounding carpet of bluish violet bugle, a plant which attracts moths, butterflies and bees, before exiting onto Fort Road their route led them past the Marconi Holiday Village and the Church of St Lawrence before heading along the clftop. With thick black clouds heading up the English side of the Bristol Channel, the race was on to get back before the rain hit. As the weather turned wintry and the wind increased, a huge shower of hailstones and heavy rain struck them on the open Penarth clftop soaking them as they made their way back to their start point.You can follow the grouprsquos exploits before, during and after lockdown on Facebook. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: sotm st richard gwyn catholic high school barry
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communitySt Richard GwynCatholic High School, on Argae Lane in Barry, has  pupils currently on roll, with this number increasing to  - the schoolrsquos biggest Year Seven cohort yet.Mr David Blackwell has been head teacher at the school since February , following his role as deputy head for more than four years.Headteacher Mr David BlackwellHe is backed by deputy head Matthew Dunn assistant headteachers Laura Burnettand Amy Leftleyand senior core leader Sharon Macleod.The schoolrsquos last Estyn report was in  ndash the school was rated lsquoadequatersquo overall but with good prospects of improvement.Explaining some of the improvements made since, Mr Blackwell said: ldquoWe have fully embedded the Jesuit Pupil Profile into the le of staff and students."The Jesuit Pupil Profile gives a focus to the citizens that we wish to nurture at SRG. It reminds staff and students that virtues towards the needs of others is paramount to the essence of our humanity."He continued: We have always prioritised wellbeing of our students but over the last two years we have developed a lsquowellbeing progress centre. Support staff have been trained extensively to ensure that all students are ready to learn.ldquoThe wellbeing team are always on hand to assist with the students wellbeing by offering sessions for ELSA, Thrive and Mental Health Wellbeing. We even have two wellbeing dogs that support some of our more vulnerable learners.ldquoWe work very closely with a iety of external agencies to support our students needs to ensure students are engaged and feel safe and secure and able to fulfil their full potential.The school caters to pupils with additional learning needs and to staff wellbeing. Staff at the school have training, progression opportunities, open door policy of support, and clear lines of communication.     ldquoTeaching and learning continues to be our core focus, added Mr Blackwell.ldquoThe  Inspection report praised students at SRG for lsquotheir positive attitude to learningrsquo. We have built upon this and we now offer a Scholarrsquos Programme to prepare students for their education pathway.ldquoWe want to offer students a chance to broaden their educational experience with us. We have broadened our option subjects at KS - we are now able to offer Construction, Health and Social Care and Textiles and Fashion.ldquoWe are committed to the promotion of SRG as a learning organisation. To this end we have entered into an ITE Partnership with Cardf politan University and an alliance with St.Illtydrsquos Catholic Comprehensive in Cardf. It is mutually beneficial since we help develop new teachers into the profession and we are able to utilise educational research to improve standards across both key stages.The Catholic school strives to ensures pupils succeed, while also being good people.ldquoWe aim for our pupils to live by the ethos of our pupil profile which is about virtues to empower them to be a success in le, added Mr Blackwell.ldquoWe are the faith secondary school of the Vale and so provide an excellent secondary education that runs equally alongside our holistic development of our pupils as iniduals and good all round people.The Catholic ethos is embedded into daily le at the school, with morning prayer, virtues-based assemblies, and daily reflection.ldquoAll staff engage in role modelling behaviour that reflects the Catholic virtues of honesty, integrity and forgiveness, added Mr Blackwell.ldquoDuring normal school times Mass is a frequent part of our school le ndash not all pupils come to us with a faith background, but they all appreciate the values that we try to weave into our everyday lives.Along with the schoolrsquos ethical focus St Richard Gwyn Catholic High School has an abundance of extra-curricular activities on offer, including school trips.Sporty youngsters can take part in football, rugby, netball, hockey, tennis, badminton, athletics, cheerleading and street dance. Therersquos also Clwb Cymraeg and an array of creative activities on offer ndash including art club, textiles club, choir, SRG band.Bi-annually the music, drama, and art departments join forces to produce and perform an arts production.St Richard Gwyn Catholic High School strives to form lsquopositive relationshipsrsquo with families and the local community and has a Facebook group regularly updated with video messages from Mr Blackwell and key messages for families.Each year group has a Progress Leader who is a point of contact for families as well as our Wellbeing and Progress Centre who liaises with families on a regular basis. Plus, St Richard Gwyn Catholic High School is in the process of obtaining the Investors in Families , which ndash in a nutshell ndash lsquois a quality mark that recognises the work that schools and other settings undertake with families to improve outcomes for children and young people.rsquoThe school is also lsquoproudrsquo to have worked with numerous charities ndash including fundraising for local food banks and helping Keep Wales Tidy with beach cleans.The school has also adapted a lsquogreatrsquo deal during the coronavirus pandemic ndash with the immediate priority being health and safety such as year group lsquobubblesrsquo, separate lunches, allocated outdoor spaces, regular sanitizing and face coverings.ldquoThe biggest impact, in terms of day to day operation, meant teachers moved more between lessons than students, said Mr Blackwell.ldquoCrucial to adapting to the pandemic was to adoption of online learning. There have been periods of lockdown with no pupils in school as well as fortnightly periods that have required year groups to isolate.He praised the training and use of online s as lsquotransformativersquo. and added that - while itrsquos lsquofantasticrsquo to resume in-person learning these changes and developments will continue to improve how the school operates.The school is lsquovery fortunatersquo to have been supported by the local authority to make the best of the buildings they have, but the school is awaiting progress on a new build under the st Century schools programme, financed by Welsh Government.ldquoWe firmly believe that what goes on inside school is more important than the way the building looks externally, said Mr Blackwell.ldquoWe have amazing staff who work exceptionally hard to make the best of the facilities we have, all pupils who come to us get a great educational experience.ldquoHowever, we are still awaiting progress on a new build. We will continue to work hard to improve our facilities with the support of our Governors and the local authority, but at the same time we will continue to lobby to get the new build progressed as soon as possible so that our pupils not only get a fantastic experience, but they also get it in state-of-the-art facilities they deserve. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityMore than  local people are urging the Cardf and Vale University Health Boardto build a health centre on Eagleswell Road, where a former primary school closed in .The disused plot of land is currently owned by Vale of Glamorgan council, and is allocated for  potential houses in the local development plan.But campaigners want the council to allow the health board to build a new health centre there, complaining the townrsquos current surgeries arenrsquot up to scratch.Councillor Gwyn John, of the Llantwit First Independent party, is organising the petition. He raised concerns that the hundreds of new houses in and around Llantwit Major arenrsquot seeing the increased investment in local public services needed to cater for the growing population.He said: ldquoThere are more and more houses in the town. Therersquos hardly any green space left and our services are really struggling.Two doctors surgeries currently cater for the town: Coastal Vale and Western Vale. Cllr John claimed Coastal Vale is ldquoat capacity and the Western Vale building is ldquoover  years old.He said: ldquoThe actual building needs replacing, itrsquos not in a great condition. It needs replacing and modernising.Cardf and Vale UHB is drawing up plans for major changes on how clinical services are delivered. This will likely see three lsquohealth and wellbeing centresrsquo with services like x-rays, out-of-hours GPs, community mental health teams, and ambulatory care.MORE NEWS:The health board is also planning nine lsquowellbeing hubsrsquo, either developing existing places like health centres, leisure centres or libraries or in new buildings such as Maelfa in Cardf. These wellbeing hubs will include GP services, midwery, and primary mental health care.     The idea is to move clinical services away from large hospitals like the University Hospital of Wales, at the Heath in Cardf, avoiding the need for people to travel long distances for care.Cllr John supports this move but says residents in the western part of the Vale of Glamorgan are currently undeserved with health services mdash and with the hundreds of new houses being built in the area, Llantwit would be ideal for a new health centre.He is hoping to get many more signatures for his petition to build the new health centre in Llantwit Major, with a table set up on the precinct in the town on Saturday, for residents who arenrsquot on the internet or havenrsquot seen the campaign online yet.He said: ldquoItrsquos all very well building homes, thatrsquos fine. But we have to have the infrastructure.The health board said any investment in new health and wellbeing centres or wellbeing hubs is some time away.A Cardf and Vale UHB spokesperson said: ldquoThe intention is for a wellbeing hub to be placed in the western Vale, but this may be some years away as part of our overall plan. In terms of where the site will be based, this will be subject to an engagement process.ldquoThere will be a health and wellbeing centre in the Vale work will be commencing in terms of engagement in relation to this within the next few months.A Vale of Glamorgan council spokesperson said: ldquoAny need for a new medical centre would be a matter for the Cardf and Vale University Health Board.ldquoNo planning application for such a building has been submitted and currently the land in question has been allocated as a signicant strategic development site for the councilrsquos house building programme. title: research shows urgent issues facing cardiff south penarth residents
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityIt comes as the UK Government is set to outline its plan to level up the country, though anti-poverty charity the Joseph Rowntree Foundation said it must improve on its "piecemeal" attempts so far.A survey by the think tank Demos asked , adults in parliamentary constituencies across Great Britain to choose which one of nine issues most urgently needs improving in their local area.In Cardf South and Penarth, .#% of residents chose good local shops.This was followed by good transport services , and housing that suits their needs .Mel Grfin, owner of Grfin Books, said she was ldquosurprised at these figures.ldquoIn Penarth I think wersquore very fortunate to have a wide range of excellent independent shops as well as a good representation of national chains, she added.ldquoYou can get pretty much anything you need in the town itself without the need to travel into Cardf. Despite the challenges of the past year, wersquove all hung in there, and I believe there are currently no empty shops in the town centre which is a great indicator for the future.Angelina Hall of Penarth Business Group added: ldquoIf we offer a good mix of hospitality, retail and services, we will ensure our High Street can prosper, attracting both locals and visitors.MORE NEWS:"Whilst City Centres have seen punishing closures leaving huge gaps in their offering, Penarth businesses have worked hard to ersy and adapt in a challenging economic climate.The most pressing issue across Britain was also shops, followed by good transport and jobs.Demos said prioritising retailers was particularly prevalent in more built-up areas, while rural communities were more likely to see a lack of quality transport as a problem.     The think-tank has urged the Government to reflect on its research as it considers how best to spend the pound. billion earmarked for a levelling-up fund to reduce inequality across the UK.In Cardf South and Penarth, an estimated % of residents think that the provision of facilities they consider most important is nearer to bad than good ndash compared to the national average of %.The Centre for Cities said the main challenge facing many urban areas is the comparatively low education levels among the workforce, meaning well-paid jobs are scarce and wages lower.A Skills and Post- Education Bill ndash new legislation aimed at reforming education for older teenagers and adults ndash was also announced in the Queens Speech.But the Centre for Cities said the Government must "make good on its promises" to improve education and training opportunitiesit is to level up less prosperous parts of the country.Andrew Carter, the think tanks chief executive, said: "Lower wages mean less disposable income to spend in local shops and other amenities. As a result many struggle and close ndash creating a general feeling of being left behind."The Ministry of Housing, Communities and Local Government said the Levelling Up Fund will regenerate high streets, upgrade local transport and invest in cultural assets.A spokeswoman added: ldquoOur Plan for Jobs will create opportunities for people of all ages wherever they live by boosting skills and giving them the best possible chance of getting a job." article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentSorry, an error occurred.Sign in or register leave a comment or rate a comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityEdwin Poots was speaking after Mrs Foster indicated thathe names his ministerial team next Tuesday as expected, she will step down immediately.She had previously said she would remain as First Minister until the end of June. She left her role as party leader on Friday.Mr Poots is set to be the first DUP leader not to take the position of First Minister. title: blockbuster movies ready for omniplex reopening
story: Traffic Attendants back on streets next week   Toddler, who died in tragic incident, is named locallyNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoHomes and GardensLestyleCarsHomes and GardensPublic NoticesAdvertise My BusinessNewsPeopleBlockbuster movies ready for Omniplex reopeningMovie buffs will be delighted that the local Omniplex chain is all set to reopen to the public next Monday - pending the easing of Lockdown restrictions.By Carmel RobinsonMonday, th May , : pm  "       "  Ready to roll out the reels, the Omniplex Cinemas are awaiting official confirmation from the NI Executive - which is due on Thursday .The cinema chain plans to begin its phased reopening of five sites, with Omniplex Craigavon Lisburn, Dundonald, Newry and Bangor welcoming customers back to a covid safe way from this date. Eight more Omniplex locations across the country are ready to resume screening from Friday th May marking the first time this year for avid movie goers to enjoy the big screen experience. ]]Craigavon Omniplex.The cinema chain – the largest in NI, closed all of its venues on December , , when all areas of the UK and Ireland were under pandemic restrictions. Paul John Anderson, Director of Omniplex Cinemas said: “We are thrilled to finally be welcoming back cinema goers for the first time this year. We strongly believe in the power of escapism that a couple of hours spent at the cinema provides and we are looking forward to opening our doors for the ultimate big screen experience. We have worked hard over the last year to ensure our customers can enjoy the magic of cinema once again. We continue to follow public health advice and the safety of our team and customers remains of utmost importance.” Safety measures will include limited capacity m distance between parties for social distancing requirements face coverings to be worn by staff and audiences when moving within cinema buildings and staggered showtimes to name a few. Omniplex Cinemas will also be operating enhanced online booking to make the visit as contactless as possible with increased cleaning regimes and hand sanitising stations in every foyer. Visitors will be expected to wear face masks but will be allowed to remove them when seated in auditoriums for eating or drinking. Paul added: “It’s been a long and dficult year for us all with restrictions affecting our daily lives. We know that our audiences are eager to get back to the big screen and we cannot wait to see people experiencing the cinema once again.” Several film studios had paused the release of their ‘tentpole’ blockbusters in , opting for release dates in the latter half of . From th May, film fans can enjoy films including Peter Rabbit , voiced by stars including James Corden and Margot Robbie and much-anticipated horror film The Conjuring . A raft of blockbuster films is set to be released in this summer with Marvel releasing the much-delayed Black Widow on th July. DC Comics will play to a similar field of movie goers with the release of The Suicide Squad on th August. The ninth instalment of Fast and Furious will come to cinema screens across NI on th July this year. The th James Bond will also grace the movie screens with No Time to Die featuring Daniel Craig as  expected to come out on th September in the UK and Ireland. Tickets are on sale now in advance of these reopening dates at www.omniplex.ie. The remaining sites in Derry, Belfast, Antrim, Carrickfergus, Omagh, Downpatrick, Banbridge and Dungannon will open again from Friday th May. Omniplex is the largest cinema chain in Ireland, with over  screens in  locations.
